legacy.full_text: @danfaggella Do you have children? If one of your children was completely digitally twinned by an ai, would that render the original child obsolete to you, or to its mother, or to itself? Certainly the set of people that care about the child would be smaller, but not zero.

result.text:
What is SWE and why are AI people suddenly talking about it?

‚ÄºÔ∏èSWE stands for Scalable Weak Supervision.‚ÄºÔ∏è

In simple terms:
It‚Äôs a way for AI models to teach themselves using a mix of noisy or incomplete data, instead of needing perfect, hand-labeled examples for everything.

Imagine you want to train a model to understand medical reports‚Äîbut labeling thousands of them manually would take forever. SWE uses patterns, heuristics, or smaller models to generate good-enough labels at scale.

Then it learns from the noise‚Äîat massive speed.

The result?
Models that can train faster, on way more data, with less human effort‚Ä¶
And still get smarter.

It‚Äôs one of the quiet superpowers behind today‚Äôs giant models.
Not all learning has to be perfect to be powerful.
